I'm doing alright, just working on some new music. How about yourself?
That's cool, what kind of music are you working on?
It's mostly experimental electronic stuff right now. I'm experimenting with some new synth sounds. How about you, what have you been up to?
What kind of synths are you using?
Mostly soft synths in Ableton, plus an old аналог poly I found at a flea market. What about you? What have you been working on?
Nice! I used to have a Juno-106, I loved its warm sound. What kind of poly is it?
It's a Korg Polysix, a classic! Have you ever used one before?
Have you ever used it for anything specific? Or just exploring its sounds?
I've been using it for a lot of basslines and pads lately. Its thick sound works really well for those. Have you done any specific music projects with yours?
Do you find it versatile for those purposes?
Yeah, definitely! It has a lot of character and can be quite punchy. You can really sculpt the sound with the filters and envelopes.
That's interesting, I've always been curious about the Polysix's filter envelope. Do you use any specific techniques to achieve that punchy sound?
I usually mess around with the filter cutoff and resonance, then use the envelope to add some snappiness to the attack and decay. I'll also sometimes use a touch of overdrive for extra grit.
That's quite a few techniques you're stacking! Does using overdrive affect the overall tone of the Polysix's sound for you?
Yeah, definitely. It adds a nice warmth and saturation without being too harsh. I like to use it sparingly though, just enough to give it a bit of bite.
That sounds like a great way to add character! Do you find yourself using that technique for all your basslines and pads, or just certain ones?
Not always. It really depends on the track and the vibe I'm going for. Sometimes a clean sound is better.
So it sounds like you really think about how each sound fits into the overall feel of the song?
Yeah, I like to think about how each sound contributes to the overall mood and atmosphere.
Do you have a preference for certain waveforms when going for a cleaner sound?
I tend to lean towards sine waves or sawtooths for clean sounds. They have a nice purity to them.
That makes sense, they have a classic sound.
"Often, yeah, they produce a nice, clean and punchy sound! What about you? What waveforms do you gravitate towards?"
"I tend to favor triangle waves for that kind of clean sound, they have a nice roundness to them.
"I can see that, they do have a softer quality to them.
"I've always found sine waves to be incredibly versatile."
"Totally agree, they can be shaped into so many different things!"
"Definitely, a good foundational wave for sure."
"Exactly! Kinda like the building blocks for everything else, right?"
That's a great way to put it!  They're like the foundation you can build upon.
"Right? It's fascinating how you can layer and manipulate them to create such a vast range of sounds!"
"Yeah, it's amazing how you can really sculpt them into almost any sound you can imagine.
"It's like sonic Legos!  You can build anything with them.
That's a really cool way to think about it!
"Glad you can see it that way too!"
"Sonic Legos, I like that!  It's a very fitting analogy.
"I know, right? It’s fun to experiment and see what you can come up with."
"I bet you come up with some really interesting sounds!
"Yeah, I'm finding it really inspiring lately! I just got a new synth plugins pack, and it feels like I have a whole new set of blocks to play with."
What kind of plugins are they?

It's a pack of vintage synth emulations, tons of analog goodness! Some classic polys, some gnarly monos. It's like a treasure trove for sound design. What about you, what are you working on these days?
"Nice! What kind of polys are in there?
It's got some classics like the Juno-106 and Prophet-5, plus some less common ones. It's fun to explore sounds I haven't had access to before. You?
Cool, I've always wanted to try out a Juno!
"They're really great for warm pads and lush textures. What kind of music do you usually make?"
I make mostly electronic music, but I like to explore different genres. I've been experimenting with some ambient stuff lately.
"Ambient is really cool! It can be so atmospheric and evocative. What kind of stuff are you listening to these days for inspiration?"
Lately I've been getting into some artists like Brian Eno and Aphex Twin. What about you, who are some of your ambient influences?
"Ah, those are some great choices! Eno is a classic, and Aphex Twin's ambient stuff is really interesting. I've been digging a lot of Stars of the Lid lately, their stuff is so dreamy and expansive.
